questions.text: A 9-year-old boy with no significant past medical history is brought to the pediatrician by his parents who are concerned about his recent onset of spontaneous bruising and a single episode of nose bleeding that took longer than expected to cease. The child has no known allergies, and there is no family history of bleeding disorders. On physical examination, the paediatrician notes several bruises of varying sizes on his legs and arms, as well as petechiae on his ankles. Initial laboratory tests reveal an elevated prothrombin time (PT) and an elevated activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), but a normal platelet count and bleeding time (BT). What is the most likely defect in this child's coagulation pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Common pathway

 

Option D:

 

Defects in the common pathway affect factors that are involved in both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways (such as factors X, V, II [prothrombin], and I [fibrinogen]) and would lead to elevations in both PT and aPTT, as seen in this patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Extrinsic pathway: A defect in the extrinsic pathway would typically lead to an isolated elevation of PT, as this pathway is evaluated by the PT test. This does not explain the elevated aPTT observed in the patient.

 

Option B. Intrinsic pathway: A defect in the intrinsic pathway would typically result in an isolated elevation of aPTT, as this pathway is evaluated by the aPTT test. This also does not explain the elevated PT observed in the patient.

 

Option C. Platelet function: Platelet function defects usually result in a prolonged bleeding time (BT) and normal coagulation tests (PT and aPTT). Since the patient has a normal BT, this is unlikely to be the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Defect in the extrinsic pathway causes elevation of PT
  • Defect in the intrinsic pathway causes elevation of aPTT.
  • Defect in common pathway cause elevation of both PT and aPTT.
  • Platelet function defect causes elevation of BT.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 120

choices.text: Potassium oxalate + sodium fluoride
Tri Sodium citrate

questions.text: As a primary healthcare worker, you collect blood samples to measure fasting blood glucose levels in a population screening for diabetes. To ensure accurate results, which anticoagulant should be used to prevent glycolysis in the sample during transport to the laboratory?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Potassium oxalate + sodium fluoride

Option C:

Potassium oxalate + sodium fluoride: Sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis by inhibiting the enolase enzyme in the glycolytic pathway, ensuring glucose levels remain stable after blood collection. Potassium oxalate acts as an anticoagulant. This combination is ideal for glucose estimation in blood samples.

Explanation:

Option A. EDTA: Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) is commonly used as an anticoagulant in hematology for complete blood count testing but not for glucose estimation because it does not prevent glycolysis.

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents blood clotting by inhibiting thrombin but does not prevent glycolysis, so it is not the best choice for glucose testing.

Option D. Tri Sodium citrate: Trisodium citrate is used mainly for coagulation tests and does not inhibit glycolysis, making it unsuitable for glucose estimation.

Educational objective:

Direct quote ‘enolase enzyme in the glycolysis is inhibited by fluoride, and when blood samples are taken for measurement of glucose, it is collected in tubes containing fluoride to inhibit glycolysis.’

 

Ref: Henry’s 21st /188, Harper 27th/152

choices.text: Platelet functions and common pathway
Extrinsic and common pathway
Intrinsic and common pathway
Vessel wall integrity and intrinsic pathway

questions.text: Activated Partial thromboplastin time correlates with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intrinsic and common pathway

 

Option C:

 

  • The aPTT or activated Partial thromboplastin time best correlate with intrinsic and common pathway activity.
  • The PT or Prothrombin time best correlate with extrinsic and common pathway activity.

 

The aPTT test evaluates the integrity of the intrinsic and common pathways of coagulation. It involves factors XII, XI, IX, VIII (intrinsic pathway), and factors X, V, II (prothrombin), and I (fibrinogen) which are part of the common pathway.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Platelet function tests assess platelet aggregation and adhesion, which are not measured by the aPTT. The aPTT test measures factors in the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways but not platelet function.

 

Option B. The extrinsic pathway is assessed by the Prothrombin time (PT) test and involves factor VII. The aPTT does not evaluate the extrinsic pathway.

 

Option D. Vessel wall integrity is not specifically assessed by the aPTT. The intrinsic pathway does involve endothelial interaction, but the aPTT test does not measure vessel wall function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The activated Partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) test evaluates the factors of the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways and is used to monitor heparin therapy, diagnose coagulation factor deficiencies, and assess the potential presence of inhibitors.

questions.text: The anticoagulant of choice for anticoagulation testing:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3.2% trisodium citrate

Option D:

Trisodium citrate is a calcium chelator and is commonly used as the anticoagulant of choice for coagulation testing particularly for tests like prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)

Explanation:

Option A. Heparin is an anticoagulant that acts by potentiating the activity of antithrombin III, thereby inhibiting thrombin and other coagulation factors. While heparin is commonly used in clinical settings for anticoagulation, it is not the anticoagulant of choice for anticoagulation testing, as it can interfere with clotting assays.

Option B. EDTA is an anticoagulant that chelates calcium ions, preventing the coagulation process by inhibiting clotting factors that depend on calcium. EDTA is commonly used for collecting blood samples for hematology studies, such as complete blood counts.

Option C. Sodium oxalate also chelates calcium ions, similar to EDTA, and is used for collecting blood samples for glucose testing (enolase acting as a glycolysis inhibitor).

Educational objective:

The anticoagulant of choice for anticoagulation testing is 3.2% trisodium citrate.

 

Question Id-15404 Unique Key-Q7889064

questions.text: Irradiation of blood prior to transfusion prevents which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Graft versus host disease

 

Option C:

 

(Graft versus Host Disease - GVHD): GVHD occurs when donor T cells attack the recipient's body. Irradiation of blood products deactivates these T cells, thereby preventing GVHD, which is especially important in immunocompromised recipients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: (TRALI - Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury): TRALI is a serious complication characterized by acute respiratory distress following transfusion. It is thought to be caused by donor antibodies against recipient leukocytes. Irradiation does not prevent TRALI.

 

Option B: (HLA alloimmunization): HLA alloimmunization can occur when a patient develops antibodies against HLA antigens from transfused blood. While leukoreduction can reduce the risk, irradiation of blood products does not prevent HLA alloimmunization.

 

Option D: (Immunomodulation): Immunomodulation refers to the potential immune system changes in transfusion recipients, potentially leading to an increased risk of postoperative infections and malignancy recurrence. Irradiation’s role in preventing immunomodulation is not clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irradiation of white and red blood cells prior to transfusion is primarily used to prevent graft versus host disease.

 

What happens in Transfusion associated-GVHD?

 

  • Donor T cells attack recipient tissues.
  • Occurs particularly in immunocompromised patients (e.g., post-transplant, chemotherapy).
  • It is often fatal.
  • Irradiation (typically with 25–30 Gy gamma rays) prevents T-cell proliferation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/e p671-2)

choices.text: WASP gene study

questions.text: A young boy presented with recurrent episodes of melena. The physician also found presence of dermatitis like rashes and multiple petechiae. His platelet count was low but red cell and white blood cell counts were normal. Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) WASP gene study

Option C:

WASP gene study refers to the genetic analysis of the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) gene. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, recurrent infections, and eczema. Given the clinical presentation described in the question, which includes low platelet count, dermatitis-like rashes, and petechiae, along with a young male patient, the possibility of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is high. Therefore, genetic analysis of the WASP gene is the appropriate diagnostic investigation in this case.

 

 

Explanation:

Option A. Anti-platelet antibodies are antibodies produced by the immune system against platelets, which can result in conditions like immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). While it could be considered in cases of thrombocytopenia, the clinical presentation described in the question is more indicative of a specific underlying genetic disorder rather than an autoimmune cause.

Option B. Bone marrow examination is a valuable diagnostic tool in cases of unexplained thrombocytopenia to assess for abnormalities in platelet production or destruction. However, in this case, the clinical presentation and history strongly suggest a specific genetic disorder rather than a primary bone marrow disorder.

Option D. Platelet function analyzers are used to assess platelet function in various bleeding disorders. While they may be useful in certain contexts, the clinical presentation described in the question suggests a genetic disorder rather than a primary platelet dysfunction.

Educational objective:

The clinical presentation described, including thrombocytopenia, recurrent infections, and eczema, is suggestive of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, a rare X-linked recessive disorder. Genetic analysis of the WASP gene is the diagnostic investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: All are true about thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grossly abnormal coagulation tests

 

Option D:

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a rare blood disorder characterized by the formation of microclots in small blood vessels throughout the body, leading to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. TTP is associated with a deficiency of ADAMTS13 (a disintegrin and metalloproteinase), an enzyme responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor. TTP doesn't grossly affect the standard coagulation tests. So, the coagulation tests such as PT (prothrombin time) and APTT (activated partial thromboplastin time) are typically normal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia: True. TTP is associated with the formation of microclots that damage red blood cells, leading to hemolysis.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: True. TTP is characterized by low platelet counts due to the formation of platelet-rich microclots.

 

Option C. Normal complement level: True. Unlike other conditions such as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), TTP is not typically associated with complement activation, so complement levels are generally normal.

 

Educational objective:

 

TTP doesn't grossly affect the standard coagulation tests. So, the coagulation tests such as PT (prothrombin time) and APTT (activated partial thromboplastin time) are typically normal. Direct lines from Robbins… “If coagulation tests indicate a major consumption of procoagulants, the diagnosis of TTP is doubtful”.

 

Mnemonic for TTP Clinical Features (Pentad):

 

FAT RN

 

  • Fever
  • Anemia (microangiopathic hemolytic)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal dysfunction (mild to moderate)
  • Neurologic symptoms

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 665

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a history of recurrent ear infections, easy bruising, and severe eczema. On examination, the child has widespread petechiae and a weeping rash over his arms and legs. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia with an average platelet volume less than the reference range. The boy's immunoglobulin levels are also noted to be abnormally low. The presence of small sized platelets on the peripheral smear is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

Option D:

Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is characterized by the triad of:

  • Severe eczema
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent infections

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is characterized by the triad of eczema, thrombocytopenia (with small platelets), and immunodeficiency, which corresponds to the clinical presentation of this patient.

Explanation:

Option A. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura [ITP]: ITP is characterized by autoimmune destruction of platelets, typically leading to thrombocytopenia with normal-sized platelets and no associated eczema or immunodeficiency.

Option B. Bernard-Soulier syndrome: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a platelet function disorder due to a deficiency in glycoprotein Ib, the platelet receptor for von Willebrand factor. Patients may have thrombocytopenia with large platelets and no associated eczema or immunodeficiency.

Option C. Disseminated intravascular coagulation [DIC]: DIC is a secondary condition resulting from another underlying disease. It is characterized by widespread activation of coagulation, which can lead to the consumption of platelets and coagulation factors. Platelet size is typically not affected, and it is not associated with eczema or immunodeficiency.

Educational Objective:

The characteristic features of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, include thrombocytopenia with small platelets, eczema, and recurrent infections due to immunodeficiency.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 243

choices.text: Normal platelet count and normal bleeding time
Normal platelet count and increased bleeding time
Decreased platelet count and increased bleeding time
Normal platelet count and decreased bleeding time

questions.text: Patient with bleeding due to platelet function defects has which of the following features?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal platelet count and increased bleeding time  

 

Option B:

 

This option is characteristic of platelet function defects. Although there is a normal quantity of platelets (platelet count), the quality or function of these platelets is compromised, which means they don't work as they should, leading to a prolonged bleeding time

 

Platelet function defects typically result in impaired platelet aggregation or adhesion, leading to increased bleeding time. However, the platelet count remains normal in these conditions because the number of platelets is adequate, but their function is compromised. Therefore, the features of bleeding due to platelet function defects include a normal platelet count and an increased bleeding time.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Normal platelet count and normal bleeding time: This option would suggest no defect in platelet function or number, which would not typically be associated with a bleeding disorder.

 

Option C. Decreased platelet count and increased bleeding time: This suggests a quantitative defect of platelets, such as thrombocytopenia, rather than a functional defect. Although patients with thrombocytopenia will also have an increased bleeding time, the platelet count in functional defects remains normal.

 

Option D. Normal platelet count and decreased bleeding time: A decreased bleeding time indicates an efficient clotting process, which would not align with platelet function defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Platelet function defects present with a normal platelet count but impaired function, leading to an increased bleeding time, whereas quantitative disorders would show an altered platelet count.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 655

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the clinic with recurrent, spontaneous joint hemarthroses. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in his maternal uncles. Laboratory evaluation reveals a specific factor deficiency. Which laboratory finding is most consistent with a diagnosis of Hemophilia A?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prolonged PTT

Option A:

PTT is prolonged by deficiency of factors XII, XI, IX, III, X, V, prothrombin and fibrinogen and drugs like hep­arin  

Hemophilia A is characterized by the deficiency of factor 8 and decreased activity of intrinsic pathway. This is associated with prolongation of partial thromboplastin time.

Prolonged PTT: This is the correct answer. Hemophilia A is caused by a deficiency in factor VIII, which is part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway. The activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT) test evaluates the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways and will be prolonged in Hemophilia A.

Explanation:

Option B. Prolonged PT: The prothrombin time (PT) test evaluates the extrinsic and common pathways.

Option C. Low platelet count: Hemophilia A does not affect the platelet count; it is a coagulation factor deficiency and does not involve quantitative platelet defects.

Option D. Abnormal BT: Bleeding time tests primary hemostasis, which includes platelet function.

Educational Objective:

Hemophilia A, a genetic disorder characterized by factor VIII deficiency leads to impaired function of the intrinsic coagulation pathway. This manifests clinically with a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and a normal prothrombin time (PT) and bleeding time (BT).

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 668

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with easy bruising and prolonged bleeding after minor injuries. She has a family history of bleeding disorders. Which of the following is caused by VWF factor deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) deficiency can lead to several effects on the coagulation process:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Defect platelet function: True. VWF plays a crucial role in platelet adhesion by binding to platelets and stabilizing the interaction between platelets and the damaged blood vessel wall. Its reduced levels lead to reduced platelet functioning.

 

Option B. Reduced factor VIII in plasma: True. VWF serves as a carrier protein for factor VIII, protecting it from rapid clearance and degradation. Therefore, a deficiency in VWF can result in decreased levels of factor VIII in the plasma.

 

Option C. Defective platelet adhesion: True. VWF is essential for the initial adhesion of platelets to the damaged blood vessel wall, facilitating the formation of a stable plug at the site of injury.

 

So, the correct answer is (d) All of the above. Von Willebrand factor deficiency affects both platelet function and factor VIII levels in the plasma.

 

Educational objective:

 

VWF deficiency impairs platelet adhesion and aggregation at the site of vascular injury, and reduces the plasma level of factor VIII by decreasing its stability in circulation.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 660

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with fatigue and widespread purpura. Blood work reveals a marked decrease in platelets, with counts persistently below 20,000/µL. The patient's history includes recurrent epistaxis and one instance of hematuria. Bone marrow biopsy reveals a hypocellular marrow with a markedly reduced number of megakaryocytes. All of the following can cause megakaryocytic thrombocytopenia, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aplastic anemia

 

Option C:

 

Aplastic anemia involves the failure of bone marrow production leading to pancytopenia, including a severe reduction in megakaryocytes. This condition is characterized by a low number of all cell lines (including megakaryocytes) and is not associated with megakaryocytic thrombocytopenia but rather with hypoplastic or amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura [ITP]: ITP is characterized by autoimmune destruction of platelets. It typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and may show an increased number of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow due to compensatory production.

 

Option B. Systemic lupus erythematosus [SLE]: SLE can cause thrombocytopenia due to autoantibody-mediated platelet destruction. Megakaryocytes may be increased in the bone marrow as the body tries to compensate for the peripheral platelet destruction.

 

Option D. Disseminated intravascular coagulation [DIC]: DIC is a condition that leads to the systemic activation of the coagulation cascade, resulting in widespread microthrombi and secondary consumption of platelets and coagulation factors. This can also lead to a compensatory increase in megakaryocytes in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In megakaryocytic thrombocytopenia, there is an increase in bone marrow megakaryocytes as a compensatory mechanism for peripheral platelet destruction, but in aplastic anemia, there is bone marrow failure and reduced megakaryocytes.

choices.text: Immediate refrigeration to preserve factor viability

questions.text: True about prothrombin time to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Done within 2 hours

 

Option C:

 

Done within 2 hours: PT testing should be performed within a specified time from sample collection, often within 2 hours, to ensure the viability of the coagulation factors, especially the labile factors V and VIII, which can deteriorate over time at room temperature.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Immediate refrigeration to preserve factor viability: While it's true that certain coagulation factors are temperature sensitive, prothrombin time (PT) testing typically requires the sample to be kept at room temperature to prevent the cold activation of factors and potential precipitation of fibrinogen. Immediate refrigeration is not required for PT.

 

Option B. Platelet-rich plasma is essential: PT is actually performed on platelet-poor plasma, not platelet-rich plasma. The presence of platelets can affect the test results by providing phospholipid surfaces that could artificially shorten the clotting time.

 

Option D. Activated with kaolin: PT is not activated with kaolin. Instead, thromboplastin (a combination of tissue factor and phospholipids) is used to activate the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. Kaolin is used as an activator in the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) test, which evaluates the intrinsic pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The PT test must be done on platelet-poor plasma and usually within 2 hours of sample collection to ensure accurate results, using thromboplastin for activation.

 

 

Ref: Dacie and Lewis practical hematology 10th/392, 398

choices.text: Most of the patients respond to immunosuppressive doses of glucocorticoids
Splenectomy is the treatment of choice for relapse
Minority have refractory forms of ITP and difficult to treat

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a diagnosis of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) returns for a follow-up visit. She previously responded well to a course of glucocorticoids but presented again with petechiae and a platelet count of 25,000/μL. She has no splenomegaly on examination. All the following statements are correct about treatment in chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Relapse is rare

Option B:

This statement is incorrect because relapses after initial treatment with glucocorticoids are common in chronic ITP.

Explanation:

Option A. While initial treatment with glucocorticoids can be effective, many patients with chronic ITP may not achieve sustained remission and can experience relapses.

Option C. Splenectomy is typically considered after glucocorticoids and other medical therapies have failed, making it not a first-line treatment, but rather a treatment for relapsed or refractory cases.

Option D. Some patients with chronic ITP do not respond to conventional therapies or relapse following initial therapy, which may suggest a refractory form of the disease.

Educational Objective:

Direct quote…. “Almost all patients respond to gluco­corticoids (which inhibit phagocyte function), but many eventually relapse.”

  • In individuals with severe thrombocytopenia, sple­nectomy normalizes the platelet counts.
  • Immunomodulatory agents such as intravenous immunoglobulin or anti-CD20 antibody (rituximab) are often effective in patients who relapse after splenectomy or for whom splenectomy is contraindicated.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 659

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent nosebleeds, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding after minor injuries. He has a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex. Glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex is deficient in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glanzmann disease

   Option B:

Glanzmann disease is a congenital platelet disorder characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of the glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex on the surface of platelets. This complex is essential for platelet aggregation by binding fibrinogen and facilitating platelet-platelet interaction. In Glanzmann disease, impaired platelet aggregation leads to a tendency for prolonged bleeding.

Explanation:

Option A. Bernard Soulier syndrome is associated with a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex.

Option C. von Willebrand disease is associated with deficiencies or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, not the glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex.

Option D. Gray platelet syndrome is a rare platelet disorder characterized by grayish platelets and a deficiency of alpha-granules.

Educational objective:

 Glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex is deficient in Glanzmann’s disease.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /120

questions.text: A newborn baby presented with profuse bleeding from the umbilical stump after birth. Rest of the examination and PT, APTT are within normal limits. Most likely diagnosis is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia > (d) Bernard Soulier disease

 

Option B:

 

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia is a rare genetic platelet disorder characterized by the lack of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa on the platelet surface, which is essential for platelet aggregation. Despite normal PT and aPTT, patients present with bleeding symptoms because the coagulation cascade is intact, but the platelet plug formation is impaired.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Factor X deficiency: Factor X deficiency is a rare bleeding disorder where the clotting factor X is either deficient or not functioning properly. It typically presents with a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), which are not normal in this case.

 

Option C. von Willebrand disease: Von Willebrand disease is the most common hereditary bleeding disorder and is caused by a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is crucial for platelet adhesion; however, PT and aPTT can be normal in mild cases, but there's often an abnormal bleeding time or abnormal vWF assays.

 

Option D. Bernard-Soulier disease: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is another rare platelet disorder, caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the platelet glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex, important for platelet adhesion to the vascular subendothelium. Similar to Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, PT and aPTT are normal, but the platelet function is impaired, leading to bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of normal PT and aPTT despite bleeding symptoms points towards a platelet function disorder rather than a clotting factor deficiency. Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia and Bernard-Soulier syndrome are both characterized by normal coagulation tests and abnormal platelet function; however, Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia is generally considered more likely when these two conditions are indistinguishable based on clinical and laboratory findings.

 

Factor XIII Deficiency and Umbilical Stump Bleeding

 

Key Features of Factor XIII Deficiency:

 

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Rare, but classically causes delayed bleeding (e.g., 24–48 hours or later)
  • Umbilical stump bleeding is one of the hallmark early signs
  • Clot is formed but is unstable — leading to rebleeding
  • PT, APTT, bleeding time, and platelet count are all normal
  • Diagnosed by 5M urea clot solubility test or Factor XIII assay

 

But it’s not in the option so the best option here is Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

 

Ref: Wintrobe’s 12th/1365-1370

questions.text: A 25 years old asymptomatic pregnant female underwent a pre-op coagulation test. Her bleeding time is 3 minutes, PT is 15/14sec, a PTT is 45/35 sec, platelet count is 2.5 lac/ mm3 and factor VIII levels were 60IU/dL. What is her most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor VIII inhibitors

 

Option C:

 

Acquired hemophilia, caused by autoantibodies against factor VIII, leads to a prolonged aPTT in the presence of a normal PT and bleeding time, which matches our patient’s coagulation profile. It can occur in the absence of an underlying condition or be associated with conditions like pregnancy, as mentioned.

 

(3 minutes is the normal bleeding time)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Factor IX deficiency: Factor IX deficiency, also known as Hemophilia B or Christmas disease, is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency of clotting factor IX. It is an X-linked recessive disorder, making it much less likely in females. It presents with a prolonged aPTT but normal PT and bleeding time, which does not fully match the patient's profile since her PT and bleeding time are within normal limits.

 

Option B. Lupus anticoagulant: The presence of lupus anticoagulant, an autoimmune inhibitor, is associated with prolonged aPTT and may also lead to a prolonged PT. It is part of the antiphospholipid syndrome and can cause both bleeding and thrombotic episodes. Patients often have thrombocytopenia, which is not the case here as the patient has a normal platelet count.

 

Option D. VWD – Type III: Von Willebrand Disease (VWD) Type III is the most severe form of VWD and is characterized by a markedly reduced or absent von Willebrand factor, leading to a significant bleeding tendency. Patients usually have a prolonged bleeding time and a decreased factor VIII activity, which is not consistent with this patient's normal bleeding time and near-normal factor VIII levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This patient’s normal bleeding time and PT but prolonged aPTT, along with the presence of normal factor VIII activity, suggest the presence of an inhibitor against factor VIII rather than a deficiency, which is consistent with acquired hemophilia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 672-3, Wintrobe 12th/1447-1453, Har­rison 21st/980
